title: Mystery Shoppers agency of the week: Britishairways.com
text:
Save 
TTG’s mystery shopper headed to Fakeham in search of flights including cycle carriage - but it was an online agency that provided the best consultation 
The mystery shopper visited two travel agencies in Fakenham, Norfolk and requested flights to Pisa for three people, including cycle carriage, in April 2016, on a maximum budget of £500. 
They then made two Google.co.uk searches using the term ‘airlines with cycle carriage’ Score: 94% 
See how they rank in our Mystery Shopper Top 10 leaderboard, updated weekly… 
Mystery Shopper said: The website was the first one listed in Google. It was easy to navigate, and looked professional. My search took me straight to a page about sporting equipment, which reassured me that a bike counted within my free baggage allowance. It was easy to search for flights from there, and the search function was easy to use. I could specify a day, and see results for three days either side. The flights were within my budget at £353 and they departed from Heathrow at convenient times too. 
There was an option to hold the flights for 72 hours at a small charge of £5pp, which would be refunded if booked. It also told me how many seats were left at that price, which created an urgency to book. There were clear benefits to booking with the airline because drinks, snacks and baggage were included. Sporting goods and musical instruments: BA’s policy Musical instruments can be taken onboard as part of (but not in addition to) the free hand baggage allowance, provided they fit within the maximum bag dimensions. A double bass cannot be accommodated in any cabin, however, it can be accepted as checked baggage. This will be part of the checked baggage allowance so excess baggage charges may apply. British Airways will accept non-motorised bicycles up to 190cm in length, provided they are packed in a recognised bicycle bag. Diving equipment is accepted when packed in a recognised kit bag and does not exceed the maximum dimensions and weight restrictions for checked baggage. Bags weighing more than 23kg (51lb) may incur a heavy bag charge. Surfboards also qualify as checked baggage, providing they do not exceed the maximum weight restrictions for checked baggage and are packed in a recognised bag or case to safeguard against damage. 
Source: britishairways.com 
﻿ 
TTG has teamed up with React Surveys to simulate a realistic booking process each week – that means a mystery shopper looking for the best deal from agents and operators on the high street, online, on TV or in newspapers. The Mystery Shopper research is carried out on behalf of TTG by React Surveys,and no further details or information can be disclosed. Researchers take into consideration first impression, sales process,product and budget match andextras offered before giving an unbiased opinion of which channel/company with on that occasion. We do not claim thatthe winneris the best in an area or specialist sector, as we may report on competing travel firms in the future. Please note that the aim of Mystery Shopperis not to criticise individual agents or companies, but to promote good sales technique for the benefit of all in the travel trade.
